page.title: 12Shotwick Village
page.content: Shotwick is a beautiful little village going back many centuries in history, when it was a very busy port.In Roman times it was used to ship Cheshire Salt.For many centuries the journey from to Chester to Shotwick was made along Saltesway which is the "Kyng's Highway near Chester to lede the hoost of our Sovreyn Lord the Kyng in tyme of warre into Shotwick Ford." The road served Shotwick Castle (which is now marked by earthworks)and is supposed to have been used by Henry III in 1245 when he led a great army into Wales and again by Edward I in 1278.The road, now a cobbled lane and a bridge crossing the little brook, still exists below Shotwick.As a port Shotwick was in its heyday in the 13th and 14th centuries.It could be that the word "wik" come from the Norse meaning "Greek".
